revised_title: Stress-Optical Effect in Transparent Solids Strained beyond Elastic Limit
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on the stress-optical effect in transparent solids, such as glass and xylonite, strained beyond the elastic limit. They found that the optical creep on loading is significant and diminishes as the load decreases. The stress-optical effect in xylonite seems to be due to two constituents with different elastic and plastic properties and stress-optical coefficients. This research has important implications for stress determinations in materials.
